       AN ACT to amend the public service law, in relation to the definition of
         alternate energy production facilities

         THE  PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section 1. Subdivision 2-b of section 2 of the public service law,  as
    2  amended  by  chapter  212  of  the  laws  of 2010, is amended to read as
    3  follows:
    4    2-b. The term "alternate energy production  facility,"  when  used  in
    5  this  chapter,  includes any solar, wind turbine, fuel cell, tidal, wave
    6  energy, waste management resource recovery,  refuse-derived  fuel,  wood
    7  burning  facility, or kinetic energy storage device utilizing BATTERIES,
    8  FLOW BATTERIES, flywheels or compressed air, together with  any  related
    9  facilities located at the same project site, with an electric generating
   10  capacity  of  up to eighty megawatts, which produces electricity, gas or
   11  useful thermal energy.
   12    S 2. This act shall take effect on the thirtieth day  after  it  shall
   13  have become a law.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S607A

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the public service law, in relation to the definition of
alternate energy production facilities

PURPOSE OF THE BILL:
This bill would encourage the development of new, clean alternative
Electric generation technologies by reducing the regulatory burden on
batteries flow batteries and capacitors.

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:
Section 1 of the bill would amend Public Service Law (PSL) §2(2-b)
would exempt batteries, capacitors and flow batteries with an
electric generating capacity of less than 80 MW, from the definition
of facilities giving rise to an "electric corporation" subject to the
jurisdiction of the Public Service Commission.

Section 2 defines the effective date as the thirtieth day after it
shall become law.

EXISTING LAW:
P8L §2(13) defines electric corporations subject to the jurisdiction
of the Commission. Cogeneration facilities (P8L §2(2-a), small hydro
facilities (P8L §2(2)-c)), and alternate energy production facilities
(P8L §2(2-b) are specifically exempted from the definition of
facilities giving rise to an "electric corporation."

P8L §2(2-b) defines an "alternate energy production facility" to
include any solar, wind turbine, waste management resource recovery,
fuel cell, tidal, wave energy and refuse-derived fuel or wood burning
facility with an electric generating capacity of up to 80 MW which
produces electricity, gas or useful thermal energy.

LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:
S.8310 of 2009-2010

STATEMENT IN SUPPORT:
Energy storage resources have the potential to offer a number of
valuable benefits to the New York electric grid including improving
the economic efficiency of the power system and enhanced integration
of renewable technologies. Currently, battery and flow battery storage
devices are not excluded from the regulatory structure of the
commission on new technologies in order to encourage their
development and use in New York State. Yet these battery systems
allow for use of electricity generated from renewable Sources or
produced during off-peak times to be used during times of higher
demand, reducing the need to ramp up more expensive - and potentially
more polluting - generating facilities to meet peak demand. Such
facilities also provide frequency and voltage regulation support to

improve the efficiency of the electric grid and, as noted, reduce the
need for traditional generation such as load-following boilers.

These facilities can significantly improve the efficiency, of the
State's electric system, allowing for the utilization of clean,
renewable resources that might otherwise not be dispatched.
Additionally, in May 2009, the New York Battery and Energy Storage
Technology Consortium (NY BEST) was created with the ultimate goal of
positioning New York as the global leader in energy storage
technology. To support NY BEST the state has set aside $25 million to
finance the development of energy storage technologies, including
battery testing, in New York. While this investment is significant,
and the consortium's mission laudable, we cannot achieve these goals
without also batteries, capacitors and flow batteries the same
regulatory advantage as-and place them on equal footing with various
other alternative production facilities in New York.

BUDGET IMPLICATIONS:
Exemption of these facilities would reduce workload for Commission
Staff.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This bill would take effect on the thirtieth day after it shall become
law.
